'Enteropeptidase' (also called 'enterokinase') is an enzyme produced by
cells of the duodenum and involved in human digestion. It is secreted from
intestinal glands (the crypts of LieberkÃ¼hn) following the entry of ingested
food passing from the stomach. Enteropeptidase converts trypsinogen (a
zymogen) into its active form trypsin, resulting in the subsequent
activation of pancreatic digestive enzymes.

Enteropeptidase is a serine protease () consisting of a disulfide-linked 82â140
kDa heavy chain which anchors enterokinase in the intestinal brush border
membrane and a 35â62 kDa light chain which contains the catalytic subunit. Enteropeptidase is a part of the chymotrypsin-clan of
serine proteases, and is structurally similar to these proteins.
